awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:   Early Evolution of Fungi and the Transition to a Terrestrial Lifestyle: Marine Habitats, the New Frontier
awd_abstract_narration:
Zoosporic fungi (fungi that reproduce through motile spores) represent the earliest lineages in the fungal tree of life; unfortunately, they are also the most poorly understood. Limited sampling of these fungi, especially from marine and estuarine habitats, constrains attempts to reconstruct the early evolution of the kingdom Fungi. The primary hindrance to uncovering the full extent of zoosporic fungal diversity is the historical reliance on culture-dependent methods, resulting in the description of only the most abundant taxa, or those amenable to isolation in the laboratory. The recent use of culture-independent molecular methods to characterize fungal diversity and community composition in terrestrial, freshwater, and extreme environments has revealed novel early-diverging fungal lineages. Additionally, these studies have found that zoosporic fungal lineages are often the dominant fungal component of their respective ecosystems. As environmental cloning studies have high time and supply costs, next-generation sequencing has been promoted as a rapid, cost-effective method for characterizing communities of cryptic microorganisms in previously neglected habitats. Several metagenomic analysis pipelines and reference databases now exist to assist in the clustering and taxonomic identification of molecular sequences recovered from environmental samples. However, the available databases are populated with large numbers of sequences from previous environmental cloning studies outside a phylogenetic framework and without a corresponding taxonomic classification, hindering efforts to classify poorly known groups. To address these issues, the research proposed herein aims to: 1) use culture-independent methods to discover novel marine fungal taxa; 2) infer the phylogenetic relationships of these taxa with all known zoosporic counterparts, consisting primarily of terrestrial and freshwater fungi; and 3) use the phylogenetic dataset produced for objective 2 to date the loss(es) of the fungal flagellum and estimate the minimum age(s) of the adoption of a primarily terrestrial lifestyle in the evolution of the Fungi.

The proposed research will provide training for a motivated undergraduate student, in addition to informing the development of child-focused interactive exhibits on fungi and their symbiotic interactions with plants and animals for two local science museums (North Carolina Museum of Life and Science, Durham, NC; North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, Raleigh, NC).

por.por_cntn:
SUMMARY & INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Fungi are among the most diverse organisms on the planet, but only a tiny fraction of fungal species—perhaps as low as 2%—have been described. As a result, our understanding of both the evolution and ecology of fungi remain largely incomplete. The research funded in this grant investigated the diversity and distribution of a particularly poorly studied group of fungi, those from marine habitats. We hypothesized that many marine fungi would belong to the most species-rich fungal phyla (Ascomycota and Basidiomycota), but that marine habitats would also include species from the earliest lineages in the fungal tree of life, contrary to historical findings. We sampled water and sediments from four coastal habitats (surface waters, intertidal wetlands, intertidal sandflats, and benthic sediments) in eastern North Carolina and used amplicon sequencing of the nuclear ribosomal large subunit (28S) to characterize fungal communities. We determined that marine fungi are indeed more diverse than culture-based studies would otherwise suggest, with fungi from across all phyla represented in all four habitats. Moreover, though Ascomycota were the most abundant fungi, the early-diverging Chytridiomycota (i.e., “chytrids”) were the second-most abundant taxa recovered. This finding was particularly important, as few marine chytrids have been described. Many of the fungal taxa recovered in this study were found to be only distantly related to other described species, suggesting that improved sampling of marine fungi could help fill in holes in the fungal evolutionary tree. These findings were published in the journal Fungal Ecology (DOI:10.1016/j.funeco.2016.10.006).

To improve the genetic resources available for these uncultured marine fungi, we then generated 2,000bp reference sequences from the same NC samples, in addition to sediment core samples we collected and deep-sea, hydrothermal vent water samples generously provided to us by collaborators. We used phylogenetic methods to assess the evolutionary relationships of these fungi and found that most represented new species within known fungal families or genera, but others represented potentially new phyla altogether. This study represents only the second to use PacBio circular consensus sequencing to generate high quality reference data for fungi, and the first to target marine fungi in particular. These sequences will be integrated into existing reference databases to improve future studies of fungal diversity and ecology. This work will be submitted for publication before the end of 2017.

BROADER IMPACTS: During the funding period, co-PI Dr. Picard received extensive training in bioinformatics, phylogenetics, and microbial ecology. Data generated as part of this grant was presented at the 10th International Mycological Congress in Bangkok, Thailand in August 2014, and the Mycological Society of America’s meeting in Edmonton, Canada in August 2015. Dr. Picard mentored over 30 undergraduate students as the graduate coordinator of the Howard Hughes Research Fellows summer research program at Duke University. She also participated in community outreach at local high schools and museums, incorporating her research into hand-on learning activities.
